Award.AwardTitle: Linear Avalanche HgCdTe Arrays for Photon Counting AO Wavefront Sensing
Award.AbstractNarration:
Since the mid 1990's, Adaptive Optics (AO) techniques have revolutionized ground-based observational astronomy at optical and infrared (IR) wavelengths. The precise sensing of the atmosphere's distortion of the wavefront from a natural or laser guide star is crucial to achieving a telescope's diffraction limit. Dr. Donald Hall of the University of Hawaii proposes to adapt, and optimize for AO wavefront sensing, sensors developed through the nation's substantial investment in space and military LADAR by producing modest format arrays and demonstrating their photon counting performance for wavefront sensing at the telescope. To achieve this, the technique utilizes the unique linear avalanche properties of HgCdTe, a substance already the material of choice for astronomy in the 1 - 5 micron waveband and the technology base for production of large format arrays for near-IR astronomy.

The project will hybridize 32x32 arrays of HgCdTe linear-mode avalanche photo-diodes to an optimized 64-output readout. These hybrids will count individual near-IR photons with wavelengths between 0.85 and 2.5 microns with high quantum efficiency, at frame rates approaching 100 KHz, and with no degradation of their fundamental Poisson statistics. The goal is to produce over a thousand readout dies and to make several dozen high-quality hybridized arrays available for initial characterization followed by deployment in telescope AO systems.

While the proposed investigation has the potential to revolutionize AO wavefront sensing and all aspects of the science it enables on ground based telescopes, it barely taps the surface of broader applications that extend beyond astronomy. The investigation will also encompass potential solar applications and likely enabling coronal AO sensing. Finally, society will benefit from the development of the technique, its application beyond astronomy, and the exciting scientific discoveries it will make possible.

Funding for development and construction of the prototype spectrograph is being provided by NSF's Division of Astronomical Sciences through its Advanced Technologies and Instrumentation program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Adaptive optics corrects the distortion caused by the earth’s atmosphere so as to allow ground based telescopes to achieve their full diffraction limited angular resolution. This requires imaging a natural or laser guide star in exposures as short as a millisecond so as to freeze the atmosphere – wave-front sensing. For the very red stars most favorable for studying earth-like planetary companions and for sources that are heavily obscured by dust, such as the Galactic Center, there are major advantages to doing this in the infrared which allows the use of much fainter natural guide stars. However such images are photon starved for all but the brightest natural guide stars, requiring high speed (by astronomical standards) infrared detector arrays with very low (sub-electron) read noise. Such arrays were originally developed for near infrared (1 – 2.5 um) LIDAR and communications applications but these can tolerate dark currents a thousand times or more the few electrons per second that are essential for astronomy.

In collaboration with the European Southern Observatory, the University of Hawaii has partnered with the company Leonardo, located in the UK, to develop and optimize the 320 x 256 format SAPHIRA avalanche photo-diode (APD) array for wavefront sensing. It utilizes the unique linear avalanche properties of the semiconductor detector Mercury Cadmium Telluride (HgCdTe) to achieve the required near infrared performance i.e. sub-electron read noise at kHz frame rates with dark current of a few electrons per second. This is made possible by avalanche gains of 5 to 500 of the charge within the APD sensor before it is read out.

These advanced sensors have been installed in three University of Hawaii “travelling” cameras, two funded by this NSF investigation and a third by a private foundation. These are opening up new areas of fundamental astronomical research. One has been deployed with a fully automated adaptive optics system, Robo-AO, at both the Palomar 60-inch telescope and, more recently, the Kitt Peak 88-inch telescope for follow up observations of hundreds of exo-planet candidates identified by NASA’s Kepler mission. The much higher angular resolution of the Robo-AO observations is critical to separate out binary star systems and coincidental field stars that can contaminate the Kepler data. The second camera has been used with the SCExAO system at the Subaru Telescope on Mauna Kea to develop techniques for coronagraphic speckle imaging and pyramid wavefront sensing. These will allow direct imaging and even spectroscopy of planets around very late type (red) M-dwarfs. The third camera is in the process of being deployed to one of the Keck Telescopes on Mauna Kea to provide a NIR pyramid wavefront sensor as part of the new NSF ATI sponsored Keck Planet Imager and Characterizer (KPIC) for the study of M dwarf planetary systems. The KPIC camera will also be used for study of the dynamics of stars with orbits that graze the black hole at the center of our galaxy. The European Southern Observatory has also deployed SAPHIRA arrays for wavefront-sensing and fringe tracking for even sharper observations of the Galactic Center black hole with the GRAVITY instrument on the Very Large Telescope in Chile.

The SAPHIRA arrays have enabled at least one commercial product, the C Red-1 camera by First Light Imaging. A number of these cameras have already been delivered for both astronomy projects and also for broader applications such as medical imaging.

The investigation has been the basis for hands-on experimental experience involving one post-doctoral fellow, three doctoral dissertations and three projects by NSF REU students – all but one of these are women and several are minorities. The investigation has also provided “hands-on” experience for a number of undergraduates at the University of Hawaii at Hilo.

SAPHIRA arrays are now being implemented in numerous adaptive optics instruments, notably in preparation for the next generation of thirty meter class telescopes, and also for balloon astronomy and related guidance systems. A number of new initiatives to further develop arrays incorporating this technology are also underway. One consortium is scaling the SAPHIRA to a 512 x 512 format. The current investigation has also demonstrated dark currents as low as a few electrons per hour in these linear APD arrays and the University of Hawaii is now funded by NASA to develop a megapixel class linear APD array optimized for low background space astronomy.
